Grievous thought it foolish to keep Maul alive, but Dooku reminded Grievous that it was not wise to question the plans of Darth Sidious, and that he as Dooku's apprentice would carry out his orders to the fullest degree. Grievous then moved his fleet to Zanbar and launched several landing craft to destroy the Mandalorian warriors, starting off the Battle of Zanbar.
Basing his calculation on their experience compared to the clones they normally fought, Grievous knew that the chances of his droid army gaining a victory in this battle were unlikely. Deploying his droids after telling them as such, Grievous watched the fighting unfold from a landing craft until he spotted Maul on the battlefield. After sending out four of his IG-100 MagnaGuards to weaken Maul, Grievous emerged from his ship and engaged at least one Mandalorian super commando in battle, easily killing him with his lightsabers. Maul disposed of the Magnaguards and turned his attention to the cyborg general and engaged Grievous in single combat. Neither Maul nor Grievous was able to gain the upper hand in the duel, but Grievous, per his orders, taunted Maul, telling him that the battle was lost.
However, Maul had held several Gauntlet fighters in reserve and ordered them to drop firebombs onto the battlefield. This left both factions' resources almost depleted. Maul, realizing Zanbar was lost, fled into a Gauntlet fighter and retreated from Grievous. Grievous then contacted Count Dooku via hologram and informed him he had fulfilled his master's wishes; Maul was on the run. Dooku then congratulated Grievous. Maul now believed the Sith were out to destroy him and his Syndicate, but would not learn of their true intentions until it was too late. Grievous knew their goal was the witch Talzin, but did not understand what value Maul held for the Witch. Dooku told him all would be revealed as their plans unfolded.
After leaving Zanbar, Dooku rendezvoused with Grievous, gathering the fleet after Separatist spies reported that Mandalorian warships were amassing on the planet of Ord Mantell, confirming Maul was in league with the Black Sun who controlled the planet. Grievous once again questioned the Dark Lord's obsession with destroying Mother Talzin; Dooku explained to Grievous that Talzin was an older and fouler creature than Grievous understood, and that she would have to be destroyed before she disrupted Darth Sidious' plans. Grievous' super tactical droid Tey-Zuka reported to the cyborg general that a lone transport shuttle had left Dathomir moments ago, with Ord Mantell being a possible destination. Dooku believed Talzin was aboard and ordered the fleet to move to Ord Mantell.
Soon they arrived and Grievous ordered the fleet to begin bombarding the city from orbit. With the city now in ruins, the landing crafts began their assault. Grievous believed Maul's forces would soon be on the run but became suspicious when he realized he had not seen any Mandalorian warships. Tey-Zuka calculated that they had been destroyed before they could lift off but Grievous knew better—they were planning a sneak attack. The Gauntlet fighters appeared from behind Ord Mantell's moon, attacking the Separatist fleet. Grievous had been lured into a trap. Tey-Zuka reported a fighter had attached itself to the hull of Grievous' Providence-class Dreadnought—but before the droid could finish, Maul interrupted. He gave Grievous an ultimatum; either he shut down the battle droids that were killing his troops—or he would die.
With the General dismissing his threats, Maul then charged Grievous, tackling him into a transparisteel viewport. Dooku had also been captured as well. Maul contacted Sidious via hologram after traveling to Vizsla Keep 09, threatening to kill them both unless he met Mother Talzin's demands. Sidious refused, instead stating he had no further use for them. Maul decided not to kill them, but ordered Grievous to the brig. Grievous told Dooku that it would be unfortunate if the next time they met he would have to add Dooku's lightsaber to his collection.
Dooku, who was still on the bridge of the ship, later used the Force to unlock Grievous' cell. Grievous escaped, killing the Mandalorians that were guarding him and several more while searching for a way off the ship. He soon found an escape pod, ejecting from the carrier and escaping from Maul.
Shortly afterward, Grievous regrouped with Darth Sidious aboard the Scimitar; which was originally Maul's personal starship; and they made their way to Dathomir where Dooku's signals were emanating from; just as Sidious predicted. Sidious ordered Grievous to cloak the ship from view and make their way to Dathomir's surface. They landed and the pair approached a chamber said to hold a stone column that was the heart of Mother Talzin's power. The chamber was located very near the Nightbrother village where Maul was born.
Grievous blew an opening in the wall of the chamber, entered and stated he was about to kill Maul. Sidious followed, stating only the Dark Lord's plan shall rule the galaxy. Dooku appeared, though he was now possessed by Talzin, who at the time was still unable to take physical form. The four engaged in lightsaber combat; Grievous attacked Maul while Sidious freed his apprentice from Talzin with the use of Force lightning. Talzin returned in the flesh while Sidious told her she was going to die here. Maul took advantage of this distraction and used the Force to shove Grievous through the opening the explosion had created. Sidious attacked Talzin with a Force lightning barrage while Talzin defended Maul and herself with magick. Despite drawing strength from her son, she was unable to withstand the combined power of Darth Sidious and Count Dooku. Grievous reentered the chamber calmly striding towards the now beaten Talzin; Grievous then ignited his lightsabers and plunged them through the witch's chest. The magicks rush out of her body once and for all. The retreating Maul looked on in horror as Talzin's body turned to stone.
As the Droid Army attacked the nearby Nightbrother village, Darth Sidious took a moment to congratulate Dooku and Grievous; Maul's future had been erased while theirs was more certain than it had ever been. At some point following these events, the Confederacy launched an effort to retake the planet Christophsis as revenge for its previous defeat. Because of how personal winning the planet was to Dooku, Ventress suspected that Grievous would be involved in the battle. Having allied with the Jedi and the rescued Quinlan Vos to try and kill Dooku again, she informed the Jedi Council of such, but their efforts ended in failure when Dooku escaped and Ventress, acting to save Vos, was killed. Grievous rescued Dooku, but Vos had redeemed himself.
Grievous fought Jedi General Depa Billaba on Haruun Kal. There his troops decimated her clone troops, while he personally engaged the Jedi Master in a duel and almost ended her life. Six months after his victory over Billaba, later, between the conversations of Rackham Sear and Kleeve, Sear discussed his plan with Kleeve. Sear suggested attacking the temple on Coruscant by destroying the main tower as a symbol of resistance to the Order. Even though the Kage captain had been properly prepared and the bounty hunter, Cad Bane, had provided them with the building plan, Kleeve first opposed it because it was a suicide mission, but Grievous interrupted, noting that the Kage warrior was a patriot, and believing that the benefits from this mission would outweigh its cost.
He and General Kleeve then sent in their top explosives expert, Captain Rackham Sear to carry out a bombing on the Jedi Temple. After Captain Sear's mission failure, Grievous then went to Kardoa with Kleeve and Sear's brother, Colonel Coburn Sear. There, Grievous saw Billaba leading the Republic forces. Grievous then demanded that she must die. However, Kleeve saw his obsession with killing Jedi as a distraction and warned against attacking before he left for Kaller. Grievous left as well for Mygeeto. However, he left Colonel Sear to deal with Billaba and her forces.
Grievous then waited for Billaba and her forces to come to Mygeeto. There, he and Colonel Sear confronted Billaba and her apprentice, Caleb Dume. The General was able to duel her again during the Third Battle of Mygeeto and after having one of his hands cut off by Billaba, was able to get the upper hand in the fight and slashed her with one of his lightsabers, seriously wounding her. Despite this, she continued fighting Grievous; however, he was forced to flee when Billaba's clone troopers surrounded him. He told her that he regretted letting her live.
Ultimately, the Republic held all the momentum for the third year of the war. Despite Grievous's successes on Dathomir, Florrum, and elsewhere, the Confederacy of Independent Systems was driven out of both the Core and Midrim worlds and were pushed to the Outer Rim Territories, and, in the campaign known as the Outer Rim Sieges, to blockade several key Separatist worlds, the Republic Military kept up the pressure. The Separatists were prevented from directly attacking the capital by Republic keeping the Nexus Route coordinates secure and was unable to use the Hydian Way to cut through the Republic's Core Worlds to reinforce worlds throughout the galaxy, and the Hutts controlled the more circuitous Triellus Trade Route, which prevented them from moving troops and supplies between their Spinward and trailing territories. This makes the Separatists particularly vulnerable to the Republic's coordinated series of sieges and drains the Separatist Council's fighting spirit.
A significant victory was required to weaken the Republic's resolve and the intensity of its assaults. However, it seemed that the CIS could recover and emerge victorious when Count Dooku informed Grievous with the news that he was expecting. Darth Sidious handed these coordinates to Grievous' fleet, along with a plan to kidnap the Supreme Chancellor of the Republic, to leap directly from the Outer Rim to Coruscant. Towards the end of the war, a Separatist surrender seemed as though it would come in due time, but the sieges also encompassed when Grievous launched a massive offensive, pushing the Republic to the brink. The Jedi Council has sent its Generals, far from the Core Worlds, to support the beleaguered clones in reaction to this overwhelming attack.
Gathering his forces for an attack on the Core's heart, Grievous thought that such an attack will cause the recall of Republic forces participating in the Outer Rim Sieges, therefore removing or at least rendering the blockades permeable. It was a risky gamble that, if successful, could signal the end of the conflict. At one point during the sieges, Grievous was aboard the bridge of a starship. During the sieges, Grievous attempted to take control of the shipyards on the planet Anaxes, where the Republic owned a number of important shipyards. Grievous's desire led to a bloody battle. Additionally, Grievous played a decisive role in the outbreak of conflict between the Wookiees and the CIS. For the Separatists, Kachirho was a key place because it was simple to defend while also being an excellent landing strip for droids. Grievous, however, was primarily interested in the Claatuvac Guild Archives, which contained a large number of unknown space roads.
Initially, the Wookiees attempted to remain neutral in the conflict, but the importance of the planet compelled both sides to enter into a series of negotiations with the royal families of Kashyyyk to tru and persuade them to join their cause. However, Grievous became impatient of waiting for a decision favorable to his interests and ordered to prepare a large-scale attack, thinking that the threat would "persuade" the Wookiees to accept the conditions posed by Count Dooku and his allies. The invasion began with a failed attack on Kachirho's refinery. At the same time, the Wookiees Chieftain Tarfful was captured by Trandoshans in an Independent mission. However, his decision turned out to be a serious mistake. The Wookiees responded furiously and declared all-out war on the forces that threatened to invade them, kicking off the Battle of Kashyyyk.
With the Republic Military busy with the Outer Rim Sieges raging across the galaxy's spiral arms, Coruscant was left with fewer defenses. With Republic strategists unworried, Sidious arranged for Grievous to launch a massive assault to capture his own alter ego, Supreme Chancellor Sheev Palpatine. Grievous, however, was entirely unaware of Palpatine's real identity. Dooku had previously relocated his command post to Grievous' flagship, the Invisible Hand, allwoing him to be close to Grievous and ensure he followed his orders. Although Grievous posed no threat to the Sith Master, Sidious did not want any setbacks to his plans. The Coruscant Home Defense Fleet was caught off guard, and, with the chaos and Confederacy navy providing cover, Grievous and a strike team could land on Coruscant's surface. In space, Droid tri-fighters quickly decimated Republic ARC-170 fighter squadrons, while droid fighters flying to the battle on the surface supported the battle droids with their passes, spraying enemies on the ground with fire, immobilizing Jedi Masters Yoda and Mace Windu long enough for Grievous to act.
Dooku remained in orbit as Grievous took a large force of MagnaGuards with him to distract any Jedi during his escape. Grievous landed in the Executive District and then appeared in Palpatine's apartment, accompanied by his electrostaff-equipped MagnaGuards. Despite Shaak Ti and Corobb's best efforts to get Palpatine to safety, Grievous fought his way through the Jedi and great amount of security forces, killing Jedi Roron Corobb, whose lightsaber he claimed, during his hunt for Palpatine. He also incapacitated Ti using electrified cables and claimed her weapon as well. He then took the Chancellor aboard his flagship the Invisible Hand, leading him to the still-waiting Dooku in Communications tower, where Dooku took charge of keeping Palpatine captive. Grievous was also warned by Dooku that the Jedi would stage a rescue mission. Grievous had already captured Palpatine and returned to his flagship by the time the Coruscant Home Fleet had finally established assault positions.
Before Grievous could escape into hyperspace with the captured Chancellor, Republic reinforcements arrived into the battle with the Invisible Hand as their main target. While the Home Fleet moved to prevent Grievous from reaching a jump point from which the Separatist leaders could escape, thus keeping the Invisible Hands in the midst of the battle, a rescue squad under Kenobi and Skywalker, who had rushed to Coruscant from the planet Yerbana upon learning of Grievous's attack, raced to board the Inivisible Hand while Commander Honor Salima of the Home Fleet rallied her vessels to stop the Separatists from escaping or disengaging. Amid the slugging match that the battle devolved into, Kenobi, Skywalker, and Clone Flight Squad Seven raced forward despite squadrons of droid fighters confronting them, resulting in many of the clone pilots being shot down. However, the two Jedi managed to board the Invisible Hand and race toward its Conning tower to save Palpatine. Upon returning to the bridge, Grievous was informed of the Jedi incursion by his Neimoidian captain, but the cyborg merely laughed at how Dooku's prediction had come true.
Fighting past the battle droids who tried to stop them, the two Jedi make it to Palpatine and were confronted by Dooku, whose presence proved to be fortunate for the Republic; the two clashed with Dooku until Skywalker bested the Separatist Head of State and killed on Palpatine's orders. His death was a major blow to the CIS. Meanwhile, the Invisible Hand was surrounded by Home Fleet Strike Group Five under by Lorth Needa, who demanded its surrender. Needa did not believe Grievous's claims that Palpatine was a prisoner on board. Although he gave the cyborg ten minutes to prove himself before his ships opened fire, Grievous did not surrender. Informed by one of his OOM pilots that they had located the Jedi in Hallway 328, Grievous had them trapped within a ray shield and escorted to the birdge by droids. Still unaware that Dooku had been killed, Grievous was overjoyed to have captured his old adversary Kenobi and finaly meet the legendary Skywalker.
The general was already overjoyed at his victory and control over the entire fleet when he was briefly distracted by Skywalker's droid R2-D2. Using that, the Jedi broke free of their bonds and destroyed IG-101 and IG-102, leaving them free to corner Grievous. Realizing that the odds were stacked against him, the general declared that Kenobi had lost and shattered the front window of the cruiser with an electrostaff. Kenobi, Skywalker and the Chancellor managed to stay in the ship, but Grievous was sucked into space. Using a grappling hook built into his arm and his clawed feet to latch onto the hull of the ship, Grievous made his way back onboard to reach the escape pods. After ejecting the rest to trap the Jedi and the Chancellor inside, Grievous escaped in an escape pod of his own. As it had been for months, Soulless One was still docked on a small landing platform on Utapau. Grievous had thus been unable to use his personal starfighter during the battle, which ended up working in his favor because he would have lost it with the Invisible Hand. The Grievous's escape pod was found by the Lucrehulk-class Battleship Profusion. With Palpatine out of his grasp, Grievous ordered the fleet to retreat before he escaped into the Outer Rim.
With a full third of the Separatist fleet used in the battle over Coruscant having suffered major damages and failures, much of the navy was decimated and could not follow Grievous to safety. Despite Dooku's death also marking a major blow to the Separatist cause, Grievous succeeded him as Head of State and rose in rank to lead the entire Separatist Alliance, leaving him with complete control over Separatist forces. Despite the usefulness of such a promotion, Grievous remained subservant to Sidious. After the Jedi successfully foiled the kidnapping, Grievous launched a desperate and brutal counterattack across numerous star systems. Despite being used in that campaign, the legions of battle droids Grievous could command were severely depleted.
In the final weeks of the Clone Wars, Grievous boarded his personal Sheathipede-class transport shuttle, bringing with him an occupying force headed for the secured planet of Utapau in the Outer Rim, where the Executive Separatist Council was hiding. Grievous himself despised the planet after his failure to acquire a kyber crystal thanks to Skywalker and Kenobi. However, Grievous had returned to the planet at the head of a contingent, deriving some satisfaction in taking the Pau'un leaders' prisoner and beginning to transform their capital into a droid factory. On the tenth level, Grievous and his droid forces docked their Separatist ship. Under the direct order of Dooku's Master, Darth Sidious, Grievous was to relocate the Council to the planet Mustafar. Sidious also told him to remain on Utapau until he had recruited a new apprentice to join their cause. Grievous failed to realize he was being tricked again.
In the days after the Battle of Coruscant, the Republic received word that Grievous was hiding on Utapau, with Sidious, under his alter-ego of Chancellor Palpatine, claiming to Skywalker that Clone Intelligence located the general. With the war coming to its close, Sidious no longer needed Grievous as his pawn, as the cyborg had played his role; all of Grievous's campaigns had served to distract the Jedi Order from learning of the Sith conspiracy unfolding around them on Coruscant. Although Palpatine advised the Jedi Council to send Skywalker to challenge Grievous, they felt a Jedi Master was needed to finally defeat the cyborg warrior, so Kenobi was sent to confront him. With the recent death of Count Dooku, the presence of the Separatist Council on Utapau, and significant victories over the Separatists gave the task a new sense of urgency. Capturing General Grievous was now perhaps a real chance to put an end to the Clone Wars once and for all. However, it wasn't the first time Jedi General Obi-Wan Kenobi had been tasked with capturing Grievous. Kenobi would need reinforcements for the mission, he joined with his Republic troops led by Commander Cody to help him.
Upon his arrival on Utapau, when meeting Tion Medon, Port Administrator of Pau City who initially assured him that all was well. But was told in whispered that General Grievous was here, they are being held hostage and Grievous is a force to be reckoned with. Midon requested for General Kenobi and his army for help in freeing the people of Utapau from the Separatist occupation. After learning the cyborg was based on Level 10, Kenobi watched as Grievous spoke to the Separatist Council, and though Nute Gunray doubted Grievous' ability to keep them safe, they followed his orders and left just moments before Kenobi would jump down to Grievous. It was a momentary inconvenience to have to order Nute Gunray and the Council to go to Mustafar, though he took some pleasure in confirming the Neimoidian' weakness. In a move unknown to the General, Sidious had warned the Republic of his presence on Utapau: Grievous was now an obstacle to completing his plans.
Kenobi jumped down from a bar above and greeted Grievous, who applauded his audacity before ordering his bodyguards to kill the Jedi Master. After Kenobi handily defeated Grievous' bodyguards, the droid army prepared to open fire. However, Grievous ordered them to back away as he decided to engage Kenobi himself, eager to kill Kenobi himself in revenge from the last time they have fought, as well as to prove he was worthy of Sidious. He immediately split his arms in four and engaged the Jedi Master in one last duel. But the injuries to his left side had not yet been treated and, as a consequence to either his negligence or a lack of spare parts, he was unable to fight as well as he used to. The two had fought before, and both were aware of their opponent's ability; it would not be an easy fight.
The Jedi and cyborg engaged briefly along a walkway suspended above the hanger's lower levels. Kenobi, who had learnt a thing or two from his multiple duels, predicted Grievous' blows, limiting Grievous to walking down the catwalk, allowing him to neutralize Grievous' usual fighting style. After a few encounters with the cyborg and getting used to Grievous's movements, soon, one of Grievous's clawed mechanical hands fell to the deck along with the lightsaber he held. Furious, Grievous launched a wild attack, but he had lost focus. As a result, Grievous lost another hand and weapon a few seconds later to Kenobi before Cody and the 212th arrived, ambushing the droid army. Fighting broke out all over Pau City between droid and clone forces. Grievous continued to threaten Kenobi, but Kenobi ended the initial duel with a tremendous Force push that disarmed the general. Dazed and unarmed, Grievous crawled towards his speeders like a spider.

Pursued by Kenobi on a varactyl named Boga, after a prolonged chase and running duel, the two soon crashed onto Grievous' private landing platform, where the Soulless One was docked. Obi-Wan recovered quickly and took the electrostaff. He disarmed him again by swinging Grievous's blaster away as he landed several hits on him, knocking him down and thrust the moose into his abdomen, but the cyborg managed to kick Kenobi. Despite that, he once boasted to Kenobi that he would never arm his bodyguard with a weapon that could harm him.
Unarmed, the opponents engaged in bare-handed combat; suddenly Obi-Wan was at a disadvantage, and was nearly beaten. However, Kenobi managed to rip open Grievous' chest plates, revealing Grievous' gut-sack. Alarmed, the cyborg tossed Kenobi aside. Grievous laughed as he approached Obi-Wan, wounded but far from defeated. The Jedi attempted to kick him in the leg, but he was almost able to break his shin. Grievous laughed even harder and flung Obi-Wan off the platform, but the Jedi manipulated his position via Force and caught hold of the edge. Grievous saw his moment coming, and would finally kill his greatest enemy. He charged Kenobi with an electrostaff, preparing to finish off his old adversary with the killing blow. However, Kenobi used the Force to summon Grievous' blaster, shooting Grievous five times in his exposed gut-sack and making the cyborg scream in pain as his remaining biological components ignited. The shots incinerated the cyborg general from the inside burning the fluid that protects his surviving organs, finally destroying him and leaving his empty shell to fall to the ground.
After years of seemingly unstoppable terror, the general's reign of terror and murderous streak came to an end, ultimately eliminating the threat. With Grievous's death, the conflict that had claimed countless lives appeared to be coming to an end. On other battlefields, Jedi generals felt victory was at their fingertips. All that remained of Grievous was the lifeless shell that was his cyborg remains; the so-called improvements he had sacrificed so much of himself to have were left on the ground by Kenobi, who walked to the empty shell and threw down the blaster, sparing his rival one more look before returning to the battle.
Ironically for Grievous, his wish to see a galaxy devoid of the Jedi Order was all but fulfilled, but only after his death; a short time after Grievous's demise, Sidious, using his alter ego of Chancellor Palpatine, ordered the clone troopers across the galaxy to execute Order 66, turning the soldiers against their own generals. Escaping from his clone troopers, Kenobi survived and fled Utapau aboard the Soulless One, running past the remains of his cyborg rival one final time but sparing Grievous no glance. Once he was defeated, Darth Sidious was able to step up and claim credit for the Separatists' loss. After 100 years, the Sith were able reclaim control of the galaxy. With the Jedi all but destroyed, Sidious transformed the Republic into the First Galactic Empire and had also managed to turn Anakin Skywalker to the dark side of the Force, making him the Sith Lord Darth Vader.
Following the success of Order 66, the Imperial Inquisitors, or simply Inquisitors, were a small and mysterious group of Force-sensitive Jedi hunters recruited by Darth Sidious and trained by Darth Vader, led by a former Jedi Temple guard, the Grand Inquisitor. In a very different way than General Grievous had, the Brothers and Sisters of the Order of Inquisitors, stripped of their identities and assigned numbers corresponding to their enlistment orders, perverted what the Jedi stood for. Similar how the cyborg General's hand could spin while wielding a weapon, the red blades of the Inquisitorius lightsabers could rotate while the hilt remained stationary in relation, creating a deadly circle of light.
Sometime between 19 BBY and 3 BBY, Maul traveled to Damanos, an ash-gray planet, in search of a Sith castle. While in the castle, Maul experienced a vision of Grievous, who approached him and recalled the last time they had met, when he had killed his precious mother while he watched. Grievous taunts him about how his sworn enemy, Kenobi, stole his vengeance from him, further asking if it brought him any comfort or peace knowing that the person who killed his mother was dead. The two engaged in a duel in which Maul cut off two of Grievous's hands and then the other. However, one of his mechanical legs kicked out, catching Maul off guard, driving him into his chest and knocking him back. Then he continued to torment Maul, asking him about his mother, brother, and how his master abandoned him when he fell. How he never leaves those behind. Despite how powerful Maul's attacks are, Grievous continues to defend himself and never makes an attack. Ultimately, Grievous was destroyed, just as Maul dreamed for so long by thrusting his blade into him, as he had done to his mother on Dathomir. Maul had defeated his enemy, but he was still gripped by the same rage that Grievous, or the spectre in his form, had foretold.
By 14 BBY, five years after the Empire took power, it was rumored that Vader was a counterpart to Grievous that Palpatine had been holding in reserve. Also during that year, Moff Wilhuff Tarkin returned to Coruscant to meet with Emperor Palpatine. While in the Imperial Palace, Rear Admiral Nils Tenant reunited with Tarkin and asked if he had been in the Western Reaches. Tarkin, who had actually been stationed at Sentinel Base as part of Project Stardust, claimed he had and was still hunting Grievous's former allies. Over the succeeding years and decades after the entire Nightsisters were wiped out, those who had survived waited for the right moment to avenge their fallen sisters. However, the survivors were unaware that the armored being wielding a lightsaber was General Grievous himself. In the aftermath of Order 66, fallen Jedi Taron Malicos lied to the Nightsister Merrin about Grievous' massacre of the Nightsisters in an attempt to manipulate her into teaching him magick. Malicos claimed that the Jedi had been the ones who ordered the massacre. It wasn't until five years after Order 66 that Merrin learned the truth from Cal Kestis. Another survivor of Grievous's massacre, Deathstick, daughter of Shelish, has carried the weight of knowing that she once belonged to something larger than herself, and it was taken away.
Years after Grievous' death, an Imperial researcher named Cylo began working on the creation of cybernetically-enhanced individuals; these individuals were designed to be possible replacements for Darth Vader as the Emperor's apprentice. One such individual, Karbin, had a cybernetic body installed by Doctor Cylo, who claimed to have been inspired by the body of Grievous.
Some time after the Battle of Endor, Temmin Wexley implied that he had downloaded some of Grievous' old programming into Mister Bones, his robotic B1 battle droid bodyguard. Wexley had indeed added Grievous's programming to his B1, though he did not fully appreciate who the deadly cyborg had been despite his programming being the most significant of the "moves" he added. Among Bones' memories was one of wielding four lightsabers with four hands and the blades spinning, like how Grievous had once dueled.
Between 31 and 32 ABY, while on their way to learn more about the long-dead Jedi and their history, Karr Nuq Sin, RZ-7, and Maize Raynshi made their first stop at Utapau. Nuq Sin recalled learning about the planet where Grievous was killed, effectively ending the war, at a school on the desert planet Merokia.
For all the suffering he had spread throughout the galaxy, Grievous was held in high regard by at least one Kaleesh; during his travels across the galaxy, an artist met the Kaleesh, who bragged about Grievous, though not by name. The artist wrote down in his journal that he was told about a revered warrior who supposedly had cybernetic upgrades for combat. When the artist's notes were published by the Graf Archive at some point after the Battle of Oetchi in 34 ABY, they were accompanied by information on Grievous and the Kaleesh.
At some point, the owner of the store, Dok-Ondar's Den of Antiquities, a Ithorian collector named Dok-Ondar, came into possession of the Kaleesh mask and the cloak which he wore as a cyborg displayed in his shop.
Half century after the Kaleesh warlord gained galactic infamy for his role leading the Separatist droid army, Grievous was referenced in several works stemming from the planet Batuu, including a toy of the cyborg general that was sold at Black Spire Outpost on the planet. After the Battle of Crait in 34 ABY, Grievous's old enemy Hondo Ohnaka featured Coruscant in his book Galactic Explorer's Guide and, due to his role in the Battle of Coruscant, included Grievous in the "Rogue's Gallery" section for the planet.
A Kaleesh warlord who stood at 2.16 meters in height, Grievous, born as Qymaen jai Sheelal, possessed red colored skin and slit-pupiled golden eyes, as well as an elongated facial structure with slitted nostrils alongside a series of four spiky growths which protruded from his chin. Often donned with a Kaleesh mask sculpted from the skull a Mumuu, a hostile predator native to his homeworld of Kalee, Grievous wore the mask throughout the duration of his people's war with the Huk. With a desire to become the leader of the largest and greatest military force within the entire galaxy, as well as possess the capability to combat Jedi, whom he had perceived as nearly invincible as a result of their powerful connection to the Force, the Kaleesh also aspired to become a great warrior and gained the reputation of an infamous warlord who developed vast numbers of enemies.
When transformed into a reconstructed cybernetic warrior following a gruesome shuttle crash, Grievous's brain was altered by Separatist engineers without conscience by the Kaleesh, which resulted in an increase in intelligence, agility and strength, as well as a deep and violent disposition for the Jedi following the false revelation by Count Dooku that the Jedi were responsible for his condition. As a result, Grievous was tall, and his metal-plate body resembled the form of a mechanical skeleton, similar to armor but welded together with no room for flesh. In almost any meeting, it was a powerful presence that could intimidate others. With his cybernetic transformation, Grievous received claw-like feet, as well as a set of arms which were capable of separating themselves into an additional set, as well as a skull-like Kaleesh mask that had been specifically sculpted for his new body, from which his eyes peered through revealed his being's cyborg nature. Furthermore, located behind a set of duranium teeth crafted to mimick those of the Karabbac beast from his homeworld, Grievous's hoarse voice was emitted from an ultrasonic vocabulator.
Alongside a hatred for political matters, Grievous had developed an understanding that his involvement in the Clone Wars was an opportunity to eliminate the Jedi Order and command the Separatist Droid Army, as opposed to serving Dooku's political ambitions. However, as a result of his preeminent desire to eradicate the Jedi, many within the Confederacy, such as General Kleeve, considered his personal goals as a distraction which prevented his successes in the war. The general himself had a deplorable lack of a sense of humor and considered killing them to be a form of enjoyment, but he was able to put his duties ahead of it. He was quite proud of his position within the Separatist organizations and told others to refer to him as "general". He was also referred to as "My lord" by members of the Confederacy military, such as Asajj Ventress and TV-94.
Grievous was known for his cruelty and ruthlessness and was seen as the Separatists' best general. Given his reputation, Grievous was feared throughout the galaxy as a strategic genius and for his hunting prowess. After Count Dooku, the Republic viewed General Grievous as the second biggest threat in the war. The Republic described Grievous as a mechanical horror, which appealed to deep-seated droid anxieties. Nothing strike more terror into the hearts of Republic soldiers quite like General Grievous. He was a symbol of terror across the galaxy, flying from one disaster to the next, whether he was sending armies against entire worlds or facing foes in close-up and deadly combat. One of the most terrifying and formidable combatants throughout the conflict, he was both a strategic mind and a battlefield nightmare. According to legend, even the Jedi shuddered when his name was mentioned and feared meeting him in battle, as none could match his sheer relentlessness and determination.
Behind Grievous' mask laid one of the shrewdest military strategists of the era — one who isn't afraid to retreat when the odds turn against him, his superiors admired his circumspect choices and shrewd tactical decisions. On even the safest postings, CIS's limited and unreliable resources have convinced him of the value of having a speedy and reliable exit strategy. Grievous views retreat as more of a setback than denying the Republic complete victory. The general favored quick retreats from battles if endangered and regularly avoided capture by Republic forces; always slipping away to fight another day, which frustrated Republic commanders who sought his capture or death. Grievous, Trench, and their fellow commanders were placed in charge of the broader campaign objectives. General Grievous' campaigns against the Galactic Republic threatened the very existence of the Jedi Order. The brutal strategy he learned as a warlord required the Jedi to command clone troopers, which are made through technological advances. Many of the Jedi Council recognized the dangers to the Order, but they were pressured by the next incursion or the next loss of a world to the cyborg Separatist Leader. Another outlined in the legend of the Battle of Alamass, Separatist leaders believed Grievous could be relied upon to complete critical missions, for his record was nearly unblemished and he was highly regarded for his tactical insight, which provided the Separatists with numerous victories.
While Count Dooku dealt with matters of state, including military operations for the Confederacy of Independent System, General Grievous supervised the logistics and tactics of its vast droid armies. The general oversaw a large number of capable admirals and generals recruited from across the Galaxy. He could impose better control over his forces, thanks to the droid commanders who eliminated the unauthorized thoughts and suggestions from underlings with internal strategic prowess. Only a few brilliant sentients, such as Admiral Trench, managed to stay in charge of offensive operations. Grievous sometimes enlists Commerce Guild forces for combat on rocky worlds or in urban areas, while OC-9 homing spider droids serve as heavy armor and siege weaponry, and modified Spelunker probe droids offer reconnaissance and sabotage.
Cold, calculating, vain, and unconcerned with the rules of combat outlined by the Galactic Accord of Systems, his cruelty was not limited to the field of battle. Civilians and other non-combatants suffered, with Grievous devastating the populations of entire worlds. His tactic was to exploit the compassion of his foes, targeting civilians and forcing his opponents to priorities the protection of innocents. This left his troops to focus on victory at any cost. The General was aware of the Jedi's soft spot for innocents, but he did not care about civilian casualties and exploited the Jedi Compassion for the clone troopers under their command, as he expressed during the attack on the Kaliida medical station. He disliked being paired with other commanders and taking orders, as it insulted his abilities as a leader and warrior. Because the cyborg saw the big picture, Dooku found Grievous a successful leader, who carried out a high-handed strategy like using hidden listening posts to ambush Republic fleets and attempting to invade Kamino to stop clone production. He used his agile fleets to his advantage throughout the war, disrupting the Republic with attacks on planets such as Falleen and Dorin. Unable to calculate where the droid general would strike next, the Republic became distracted and left previously conquered worlds to fall under Separatist control.
Being in command of the largest droid army ever created, even when Grievous made mistakes his setbacks were often only temporary. He did suffer defeats, however, General Grievous and Asajj Ventress' failures were never serious enough to undermine Darth Sidious' plans, both agents needed to be reminded that they were not irreplaceable. Grievous' reputation of being a cunning wraith who dived in and out of conflicts silently and swiftly served as a valuable weapon in the armory of the Confederacy of Independent Systems, and his personal starfighter was an continuation of that reputation. He regularly commanded naval engagements from his flagship dreadnought, the Invisible Hand, but his combat experience and brutality shined in hand-to-hand combat. Leading an army of droids, he unleashed his full power as a cyborg general but preferred to fight from the front lines, and was often surrounded by IG-100 MagnaGuards. He crushed all, even Jedi, who came within his reach in a terrifying display of lightsaber prowess as well as the strength and resilience of his mechanical body.
Not only was General Grievous a callously brilliant strategist, but his own skills as a warrior made him a deadly opponent in his own right. The General demonstrated that one need not be strong in the Force to threaten even the greatest Jedi in combat, Grievous believed himself to be a superior warrior to all Jedi, frequently sought to prove himself in combat, and believed that his mechanical limbs made him superior to all foes. He had little understanding of the Force, though he believed that the improvements made to his body gave him a greater power than that of the Jedi he hunted. He replaced this gap of knowledge with an appetite for destruction, especially of the power he did not truly comprehend. However, transforming his body into a fighting machine left Grievous' organic anatomy weak inside his armor.
Grievous' hatred for the Jedi was well known throughout the galaxy and was stated by him on many occasions. A feared Jedi hunter, he was well known for his brutality and ruthlessness. He took macabre delight in defeating Jedi on the battlefield. However, he was also quick to run from a fight when the tide was turned against him, often scuttling away to safety using all four limbs. This tactic worked, until his final encounter with his nemesis, Jedi master Obi-Wan Kenobi, with whom Grievous shared a fierce rivalry. The Jedi considered such devious tactics to be cowardly, but Grievous held no such notions of honor. Though Mace Windu and the rest of the Council branded Grievous a coward, the truth was that he was a relentless and experienced enemy, who despite not being able use the Force, defeated numerous foes.
Grievous also showed signs of being sadistic and was only in it for the slaughter, and for Jedi like Obi-Wan Kenobi, he would spare the lightsaber in favor of a torture device to make their deaths slow and painful. He couldn’t even resist to broadcast the torture by hologram to the Jedi just to hurt them mentally. The General had supreme confidence in his own abilities, and was often arrogant, believing himself to be untouchable. Grievous also insisted on fighting Jedi personally whenever possible, even when injured, which betrayed a sense of recklessness and restlessness in the cyborg general. This was shown by his refusal to heed EV-A4D's advice to recuperate after his first bout with Kit Fisto and his former apprentice Nahdar Vebb. He acted recklessly again when he fought Obi-Wan on Utapau, which proved to be his undoing.
Grievous was a collector, who took pride in his growing collection of war trophies, which was made up of the lightsabers of his defeated foes and the braids of Padawans struck down before their knighting. He was said to have captured or killed dozens of Jedi, including Jedi Master Neebo and the recently knighted Nahdar Vebb. By the end of the Clone Wars, he had about a hundred lightsabers in his macabre collection, which he collected from Jedi who became his victims and reveled using them. The general challenged Jedi Generals in hopes of adding their lightsabers to his collection, Anakin and Obi-Wan managed to avoid being included to Grievous' list of victims.
Grievous kept a gloomy trophy room in his hidden lair and carried many stolen lightsabers in the lining of his cape, sometimes attached to his waist. Although Grievous killed many Jedi during the Clone Wars, his greatest prizes were the lightsabers of Pablo-Jill, Eeth Koth, Roron Corobb, and Shaak Ti. Nahdar Vebb's lightsaber was briefly a part of his collection but was lost when Kit Fisto reclaim it. At one point, Grievous gained the lightsaber of Jedi Master Jmmaar.
His vicious streak extended beyond the Jedi, as he personally killed Gungan General Tarpal on Naboo after killing several Gungans and massacred the Nightsisters of Dathomir. There, he showed no mercy as he wiped out the majority of the clan of witches, including the clan's elder, Daka, effectively eliminating resistance to the massacre. However, Mother Talzin escapes, but Sidious corners her on Dathomir, and Grievous has the honor of definitively ending her life.
Despite his actions in the war, Grievous was loyal to both of his masters, Count Dooku and Darth Sidious, who both frequently viewed him as nothing more than a useful tool that played an important part in their plan for the Clone Wars. While Grievous had minor clashes with Dooku, he held great respect for the Confederacy's leader, who assisted him in his training and whose orders he followed. He shared his master's confidence, such as when Dooku informed him of Savage Opress's growing power, to which Grievous simply laughed at the notion that Opress could pose a threat to them. When Dooku was captured by some common pirates, Grievous was overjoyed at the fallen Jedi's frustration. However, hubris in battle was always risky, which resulted in Grievous's surprising capture by Gungans. Following Dooku's captured by Maul to Dathomir, Grievous was trusted enough to be Darth Sidious' only backup for their final confrontation with Talzin and Maul.
When Count Dooku died at the hands of Anakin Skywalker, the cyborg general did not mourn his death. Grievous vowed that he would never forgive Dooku for leading the Republic to his home on Vassek. In a meeting with Darth Sidious and other Separatists, General Grievous learned of a new and even more powerful "apprentice" but never learned of their identity. Grievous wanted to prove his worth to Sidious and was determined to be the one to kill Obi-Wan Kenobi in revenge for their previous duel. Grievous also valued loyalty and patriotism in others, one of whom was Kleeve and Rackham Sear. He even praises Gha Nachkt's work in extracting data from R2-D2 and was seemingly intent on following through on their bargain, at least until Nachkt tries to demand more money.
General Grievous and Asajj Ventress shared a deep rivalry, implied a constant dispute between them, which often caused them to work separately. Even though they were technically on the same side, this suited Count Dooku only too well and was very much the Sith way. Grievous and Ventress were constantly tested and challenged by Dooku, who in turn was ruthlessly tested by Sidious. Grievous seemed to hold a little respect for her, as he praised her on her style and noted that they could be equals, but Ventress dismissed the idea. However, the general openly declared himself that he had always been superior to her. The two did shared a similar trait: a dislike for battle droids. One of many Separatist commanders that have grown frustrated by the droids' limitations under their command. Both also shared a deep hatred for the Jedi for their own reasons; for Grievous, the Jedi interfered in his war against the Yam'rii and sided with them, leaving his people to starve. While Ventress's hatred for the Jedi began when they abandoned her master on Rattatak.
Grievous had always disliked Nute Gunray, the Neimoidian Viceroy who led the Separatist Council, Gunray, in turn, despised Grievous for Count Dooku preferential treatment of the cyborg. He threatened to kill Gunray, when the Neimoidian was brave enough to publicly criticize the cyborg. Gor was one of the few creatures that Grievous cared for, displaying a certain affection for his cyborg pet and being dismayed upon learning of the creature's death, which became another reason for his hatred of the Jedi. He also developed a kind of bond with his medical droid EV-A4-D, though he yelled at him from time to time and humiliated him, he let him criticize him without tearing him apart. Grievous shared his secrets with his medical droid, one of the few entitles in the galaxy who knew Grievous's secrets. Whenever the general in battle, A4-D take care for his master's pet.
Despite leading the Separatists' droid armies, Grievous also had a disdain for battle droids, especially B1 models, considering them weak, incompetent, and manufactured to perform a mission far beyond their abilities. He was not afraid to demonstrate his frustration through physical cruel punishment, and would not hesitate to destroy or abandon them in an instant. Legend claimed he was so willing to harm them because, in some ways, the droids reminded him of his own flaws. Grievous's weakness was that he did not understand how much better his enhanced cybernetic abilities were than the slower-minded droids under his command. This habit often caused Dooku to remind Grievous that the droids were expensive and that they were made to follow orders, not question them.
According to the legend, Grievous could not see the similarities between himself and the droids he harassed, believing that his organic heart made him stronger and better than the droids he tried to think he was nothing like. He is often displeased with the droid army's failure to fulfill his exacting standards, distracting him just after they had suffered a humiliating defeat but the general had little regard for them and took pleasure in being the commander of the largest droid army the galaxy has ever seen. Given how much General Grievous despised battle droids, one can imagine how resistant his mechanized MagnaGuards were to their lord's high expectations. He outfitted them with Kaleesh cloaks and head wraps echoed the outfits worn by his companions as a tribute.
General Grievous resembled something from a nightmare caused by the spice, rather than something from reality. He was more machine than living creature, but the slitted eyes that peered through the white mask revealed a terrible malice and beneath Grievous' bonelike armor beats the heart of an evil warlord. Grievous, a cyborg who was incredibly powerful, reacted violently and felt humiliated if anyone mistaken him for a droid. Even so, Grievous recognized that his new form was frightening. Grievous has claimed that he underwent a complete body reconstruction in an effort to gain an advantage over Jedi and sensitive about his upgrades, claiming them to be "improvements" to the droid EV-A4-D. He would come to reflect on the life he had lost after being transformed into a murderous cyborg with one obsession: killing Jedi. Legend specified in order to enjoy the benefits of both organic and inorganic lifeforms, he believed he could be as strong and versatile as a droid, with all the cunning, passion, and capacity for emotion of an organic being.
The legend of the Battle of Alamass made further claims about Grievous's mental state; despite his military prowess, the general was still unhappy, for though he changed his body, he was not satisfied with his fate in life. In truth, he would never find peace or completion in the continued modification of his form, for deep down he sought escape, and no matter how much he might change what he was, he could never change who he was. The general, however, being a creature who was ruled by his heart, however, the general could never see that in himself. As a result, the general who would become a cyborg was a troubled soul, and he expressed his troubles by the only means he knew how-violence. Grievous became angrier and more vengeful he became, lashing out at anybody he thought was weak.
The pathological hatred he felt toward the Jedi, against whom he had sworn to exact a terrible vengeance for crimes against him and his people, caused Grievous to target Jedi one by one. After the catastrophic intervention of the Galactic Republic and Jedi in a conflict between his people and the Huk decades earlier, Grievous believed it is his duty to rid the galaxy of Jedi "filth."
Although devoid of a powerful connection to the Force, Grievous was a highly skilled warrior who was capable of proficiently wielding lightsabers in combat against his enemies as a result of the training received from Count Dooku. A master of several forms of lightsaber combat, Grievous was capable of quickly adapting to the fighting styles implemented by his opponents. Furthermore, due to the enhancements provided to him by his cybernetics, the Kaleesh often utilized and relied on his strength and agility during his encounters with Jedi.
A skilled lightsaber combatant who specialized in the form known as Jar'Kai, which contributed to his personalized style of combat, Grievous utilized the advantage of his additional limbs during battle with others, which thereby allowed him to wield four lightsabers as a result and employ a personalized variation to overwhelm opponents. With three key elements: fear, surprise, and intimidation. One of the most significant elements in undermining an enemy's abilities is surprise. Throughout the duration of his time as a warrior, Grievous clashed blades with numerous Jedi, such as Jedi Master Obi-Wan Kenobi on several occasions throughout much of the Clone Wars, as well as Ahsoka Tano, the Padawan of Anakin Skywalker, whom he was able to quickly overpower in their first encounter by rendering her unconscious for several seconds after tossing her to the side during their aboard Skytop Station, where he utilized intimidation tactics, such as roaring, to discourage his opponent. However, while Tano had improved by the time of their second encounter on the planet Florrum, as she utilized the Force to gain an advantage, Grievous was once again able to overpower the Padawan through the implementation of his additional limbs and clawed feet.
According to the Kaleesh himself, he was able to withstand assaults from strike teams of Jedi. Members of the Jedi Council struggled to challenge the Kaleesh cyborg, such as Eeth Koth; Grievous dueled Koth and was able to push him back, although he then used his MagnaGuards to subdue him. He dueled Kit Fisto despite being weakened from recent damages; Grievous's lightsaber skills were superior to the Jedi Master Kit Fisto and was able to at least held his own, even after having lost one hand until the MagnaGuards arrive and corner Fisto. Once, Grievous fought Master Adi Gallia in the middle of a firefight, defeating her and taking her as prisoner. When battling Obi-Wan Kenobi, they often fought to a stalemate or an interruption, on Caliban; onboard Grievous' superweapon battle cruiser, the Malevolence; aboard the cruiser Steadfast in the Saleucami system; on Kamino; and aboard Kenobi's command ship the Negotiator near Florrum.
Although Grievous almost defeated Kenobi multiple times, Grievous successfully defeated him above Utapau, yet was later slain on that same planet by him. Their great battle to the death has become legendary. He fought Depa Billaba in at least two different duels; he severely injured Depa Billaba and nearly killed her in their first duel such that she fell into a coma for six months. In their second duel on Mygeeto, Billaba cut off two of his upper hands, although Grievous landed a glancing blow on her back. At some point, Grievous even confronted young Caleb Dume, the Padawan of Depa Billaba. During his mission to capture the Chancellor, Grievous dueled Shaak Ti; Ti managed to fight further, but Grievous managed to get the upper hand. He ensnared her with electrified cables, which knocked her unconscious.
Beside the Jedi, he was also able to compete with opponents such as Asajj Ventress in two different duels; he first dueled her on Dathomir. Later, during the mission to assassinate Count Dooku, Grievous had tumbled over a railing while grabbing Ventress along with him. He landed on top of her with his foot pressing into her throat and grabbed Ventress with his four hands, throwing her down to the level beneath. Though Ventress managed to survive her fall, she was able to fight off Grievous. Earlier in that mission, he also fought Quinlan Vos; an unarmed Grievous overpowered an armed Vos, clashing in midair, knocking Vos back toward the wall. Initially, Vos snatch two lightsabers away from the general and then cut off one of Grievous's hand. Though Vos struggled, he locks him in a chamber. Grievous also encountered the former Sith Lord Maul, whom Grievous considered too dangerous to let live; in two separate duels to a stalemate, at least making the two equals.
He chose a very unorthodox style while contending with the Jedi, using his four arms to his advantage. While Grievous had no Force ability, he countered his lack of supernatural abilities with his upgraded cybernetics: his artificial limbs and cybernetic systems allowed the reflexes and agility that made him deadly to the Jedi whom he ran into. He could split his two arms into four, allowing him to wield four lightsabers at once. He also used his mechanical arms to rotate his lightsabers so rapidly that they became pinwheels of destructive energy. Most Jedi he came across were quick enough to avoid this strategy. He could also rotate his torso; when clones piled on top of him during the Battle of Saleucami, he used that ability to throw the troopers off him. Grievous was able to deflect a number of boomas from Gungans before being subdued by Tarpals, and he was able to deflect blaster bolts, even multiple ones, by whirling his lightsabers from two clones, Grey and Styles while Dume and Billaba surrounded him from behind. Even perfectly blocked a lightsaber strike from behind and in front.
Grievous was very fast as he was able to use his cybernetics to crawl on the ground and make a quick escape if he needed to. Even after his legs were severed, the cyborg was able to escape since his limbs allowed him to climb onto the roof. He even dodged refracted beams from a giant kyber crystal after Obi-Wan had shot it several times, causing it to overload. Not only was he fast, but he also had enhanced strength as he utilized his four arms, and sometimes two arms in hand-to-hand combat, fighting with a unique style with his bare hands, being able to lift, throw, smash, and choke his opponents. He also uses his powerful magnetized claws to kick, grab, and throw his opponents, crushing them under his feet. His durasteel feet were magnetized and so sharp that they were effectively talons, allowing him to climb walls and ceilings with ease, even grab a weapon like an electrostaff, which he could then transfer to his hand. He was capable of lifting a varactyl off his body, and pushing his way through and crushing the armor and skulls of Mandalorian soldiers with his bare hands and feet.
Aside from his growing collection of stolen lightsabers, Grievous was willing to go to any length and use any weapon to win a battle. Sometimes, he would surprise his opponent by taking out one of his extra arms to subdue them. The General did this when he blocked Nahdar Vebb's lightsaber with his own while he grabbed a blaster with another arm, allowing him to shoot Vebb several times in the torso. Against Obi-Wan Kenobi, he used one of his arms to grab him and threw him to the ground, then attempted to crush him beneath his mechanical feet.
Grievous was very durable due to his cybernetics, and could even resist explosions from fuel barrels, but his biological remains weren't. He could face even the most fearsome opponent without concern of pain or wounds because to the loss of nerve endings and easily destroyed limbs. He also didn't have to hold back his onslaught for fear of retaliation. Although he frequent took damage in battle, where he returned on occasion for repairs and medical examinations. The cyborg, unharmed by his injuries, could afford to lose a limb or two in battle, unlike most foes, which would only slow him down but not stop him.
He was unhurt from taking damage on different occasions; unhurt from being hit with the Force hard enough to fracture a ship's window, even unhurt from being tackled against the ship's window, but seemed to have little effect on him. He was still able to escape after being Force pushed into a ceiling and then falling down, although he did lose two lightsabers. Grievous took no damage after his speeder crashed into a herd of varactyls and later, he suffered no damage walking through Talzin's force field as it was bombarded with Force lightning by Sidious and Dooku. Grievous' mechanical body was equipped with duranium armor plating protecting his limbs, a torso made with durasteel, and a chest-plate cover for his internal organs, which would deflect blaster bolts. Grievous's mechanical body allowed him to operate in the vacuum of space and underwater for short periods without additional life support, he was also immune to poisons and toxins.
Grievous was also a competent strategist as he used his massive army to overwhelm his opponents. He led a devastating campaign in the Outer Rim, crushing multiple legions and fleets along the way. In the Battle of Bothawui, he commanded his fleet through Bothawui's planetary ring using asteroids to his advantage, knowing that it would protect him from any surprise attacks. This tactic allowed Grievous to damage a Republic cruiser until his adversary Skywalker knew what he was planning to do. Grievous's threat was serious enough for the Council to dispatch a team of their best Jedi: Obi-Wan Kenobi, Anakin Skywalker and Adi Gallia, when he captured Eeth Koth and used him to mock the Jedi Council. He was able to correctly anticipate the Republic's movements during the Battle of Saleucami. Grievous aware that the clones were superior to his droids and was also able to fool the Republic forces during the Battle of Kamino, with his ships taking heavy casualties, but Obi-Wan Kenobi eventually identified his plan. Later, he led his ships to victory against Kenobi's and took over his flagship without losing a single capital ship. Kenobi was considered one of the Republic's best generals.
He can calculate with certainty, based on experience that the odds are against them at the Battle of Zanbar. Grievous’s army crushes Maul's Shadow Collective in two consecutive battles, even on the verge of victory at Ord Mantell. He was also able to recognize that Maul had yet to deploy warships during the Battle on Ord Mantell. Tey-Zuka calculated that the enemy ships had been destroyed, but then their dreadnought was hit, and Grievous recognized that they had been lured into a trap. He managed to lure Depa Billaba into a trap, cutting off her exits and surrounding her with droids on Mygeeto. He also had an advantage because he could directly command his battle droids with his two antennae built into his head and even access the system via comlinks built into his cybernetic systems, directing the Invisible Hand's defense.
Grievous was not only skilled in lightsaber combat, as he also owned a custom DT-57 "Annihilator" blaster pistol called the "Grievance Striker." He occasionally also use other weapons, such as the model of blaster pistol, DC-17, with which he slew Jedi Knight Nahdar Vebb. Grievous was equipped with grapple lines built into his wrist, which he could launch the line at a long distance to attach to things. The General gained a reputation as a talented flier and piloted a customized Belbullab-22 starfighter known as the Soulless One. He was skilled enough to avoid and escape Anakin Skywalker's starfighter.
Grievous was developed for the 2005 movie Star Wars: Episode III Revenge of the Sith as a new villain on the side of the Confederacy. He was introduced in "Chapter 20" of the animated series Star Wars: Clone Wars, which aired over a year before the film's release, but his appearances in that series have been relegated to the Legends continuity. In Revenge of the Sith, actor Gary Oldman was originally cast to voice the character, but union complications forced Oldman to step away from the film. The actor was replaced by Matthew Wood, the film's supervising sound editor who would go on to voice Grievous in the 2008 animated series Star Wars: The Clone Wars.
During the development of Revenge of the Sith, Grievous was created when it was clear that, with Dooku dying early in the film, the movie would need a new villain. Director George Lucas requested Lucasfilm's art department make a "droid general," specifying that the character needed to be reminiscent of the Original trilogy's Darth Vader without being a copy of the famous Sith Lord. Lucas also noted to the crew that Grievous needed to clearly and visually be a cyborg, denying early designs that depicted his mask with robotic photoreceptors. Amongst the artists who made designs for Grievous were Derek Thompson, Erik Tiemens, Alex Jaeger, and Warren Fu; the latter was the man whose concept was made into Grievous, even thought it was only a quick sketch that he was not very impressed by. Lucas, meanwhile, was instantly impressed by the drawing.
When interviewed The Star Wars Archives: Episodes I–III, 1999–2005, Wu stated Grievous's white coloration was created to be the opposite of Darth Vader's black suit, further noting that, within Chinese culture, the color of white represents death. Another one of Fu's concept drawings for Grievous was made into his IG-100 MagnaGuards. Grievous's design was finalized around the end of 2002, only six months before shooting for the movie began. Before Matthew Wood was cast in the role of Grievous, British actor Gary Oldman was offered Grievous' role. Oldman expressed excitement at joining the film and was slated to provide Grievous' voice at Skywalker Ranch during post-production of Revenge of the Sith, but it turned out that the film was being developed by filmmakers who weren't part of the Screen Actors Guild, of which Oldman is member from, leading Oldman to decline the role out of respect and solidarity to the Guild and to avoid violating the union's rules.
During production, the crew found it hard to film the duel between Kenobi and Grievous when the cyborg warlord uses all four of his hands. After considering having one actor sit atop another or having one suspended from the ceiling to achieve the tall general's multiple armed attack run, it was decided to use two stunt performers, with one standing in front of the other, to achieve the scene, but it was decided this strategy did not work out. Their next idea was to have one performer learn both Grievous's above and below attacks, allowing the complete attack run to be assembled out of both passes in post-production. In the end, it was decided that Grievous should lose several of his hands quickly to make filming easier on the crew, explaining why Grievous only briefly uses all four of his limbs to duel in Revenge of the Sith.
